text:
Im having this issue with my mainnet validator node setup.  My svSponsorAddress  for onboarding is "<https://sv.sv-2.global.canton.network.digitalasset.com>" however it seems that this sv is unreachable from my node.
Seeing this error in the validator-app logs.

```{"@timestamp":"2025-05-13T22:01:46.193Z","@version":"1","message":"Retrying on same error kind transient error (request infinite retries) for StatusRuntimeException/UNAVAILABLE: Deliberately enforcing a retry on failed scans.","logger_name":"o.l.s.s.a.a.c.BftScanConnection:validator=validator_backend","thread_name":"canton-env-ec-45","level":"DEBUG","level_value":10000,"span-id":"05c7f0b3cea20826","trace-id":"74c616b2d36824497f49cbbbacbd3a21","span-name":"refresh_scan_list"}
{"@timestamp":"2025-05-13T22:01:49.772Z","@version":"1","message":"The operation 'Get app version of <https://sv.sv-2.global.canton.network.digitalasset.com/api/sv>' failed with a retryable error (full stack trace omitted): org.apache.pekko.stream.CompletionTimeoutException: The stream has not been completed in 20 ```
Checks from the node are timing out
```root@cli-748bdbf4f9-dtp2l:~#  curl -sSL --connect-timeout 5 --fail-with-body <https://scan.sv-2.global.canton.network.digitalasset.com/api/scan/version> | jq -r '.version'      
curl: (28) SSL connection timeout
root@cli-748bdbf4f9-dtp2l:~# grpcurl --max-time 10 <http://sequencer-2.sv-2.global.canton.network.digitalasset.com:443|sequencer-2.sv-2.global.canton.network.digitalasset.com:443> grpc.health.v1.Health/Check
Failed to dial target host "<http://sequencer-2.sv-2.global.canton.network.digitalasset.com:443|sequencer-2.sv-2.global.canton.network.digitalasset.com:443>": context deadline exceeded
root@cli-748bdbf4f9-dtp2l:~# curl <http://ifconfig.me|ifconfig.me>
51.159.77.4```
The other SVs are fine.

text:
Hey <@U03HMUTQ5F0>, managed to setup the Devnet node and we'd have a few questions:

1. The setup so far is using docker compose, without authentication. While this is less secure by default, we have restricted port 80 and we're only tunneling it to access the wallet and cns locally, with no one else having access to it. We're closing the tunnel again after performing wallet operations. Is this setup appropriate for the Mainnet node also or do we have to setup the authentication?
2. Are there any available metrics or specific logs we could monitor to make sure our nodes are running well?
3. What are the exact operations we can perform with our wallet? How can rewards be withdrawn?
4. What protocol is Canton using (e.g. PoS, PoA)? Is it possible for nodes to get delegations?
5. I have backed up the following keys. Is this enough?
```"keys":[{"keyPair":"KEY","name":"namespace"},{"keyPair":"KEY","name":"signing"},{"keyPair":"KEY","name":"encryption"}]```
Waiting on your reply on the above before proceeding with Mainnet node. Also, if necessary, please feel free to redirect me to anyone else or to any docs I might've missed.

elements.text: Hey
, managed to setup the Devnet node and we'd have a few questions:

The setup so far is using docker compose, without authentication. While this is less secure by default, we have restricted port 80 and we're only tunneling it to access the wallet and cns locally, with no one else having access to it. We're closing the tunnel again after performing wallet operations. Is this setup appropriate for the Mainnet node also or do we have to setup the authentication?
Are there any available metrics or specific logs we could monitor to make sure our nodes are running well?
What are the exact operations we can perform with our wallet? How can rewards be withdrawn?
What protocol is Canton using (e.g. PoS, PoA)? Is it possible for nodes to get delegations?
I have backed up the following keys. Is this enough?
"keys":[{"keyPair":"KEY","name":"namespace"},{"keyPair":"KEY","name":"signing"},{"keyPair":"KEY","name":"encryption"}]
Waiting on your reply on the above before proceeding with Mainnet node. Also, if necessary, please feel free to redirect me to anyone else or to any docs I might've missed.

text: If im right while we backup the node identity we can recover the node from 0 and just use a different paricipant ID with recovering the Identity on start.sh ?

elements.text: If im right while we backup the node identity we can recover the node from 0 and just use a different paricipant ID with recovering the Identity on start.sh ?

text: I see, anyone else that could help? Would really appreciate

elements.text: I see, anyone else that could help? Would really appreciate

text:
hey there, some of my thoughts:
1. i would definitely get authentication setup. if someone gains access to your system or IP space through malware or a vulnerability they would have access to transfer out coin at will.
2. yes, the docker logs can be monitored there is also calls that can be made to the node itself: <https://docs.sync.global/deployment/observability/index.html>
3. once you are setup and in your wallet you can see the operations. involves things such as transfers and you can programatically interact with the node to perform actions outlined in the docs <https://docs.sync.global/app_dev/overview/index.html>
4. there was recently a lot of discussion on this on the forum I believe. check out <https://lists.sync.global/g/globalSyncForum/>
5. follow this for identity backup: <https://docs.sync.global/validator_operator/validator_backups.html#backup-of-node-identities>
hope this helps
